title: Toward Carnot Efficient High Output Power Heat Engines Using Bubbly Two-Phase Flow.pdf
abstract: 8 *Correspondence: sdmiron@campus.technion.ac.il 9 **Correspondence: carmelr@technion.ac.il 10 4These authors contributed equally. 11 SUMMARY 12 Thermodynamic gas power cycles achieving Carnot efficiency require isothermal expansion, 13 which is associated with slow processes and results in negligible power output. This study 14 proposes a practical method for rapid near-isothermal gas expansion, facilitating efficient heat 15 engines without sacrificing power. The method involves bubble expansion in a heat transfer 16 liquid, ensuring efficient and near-isothermal heat exchange. The mixture is accelerated through 17 a converging-diverging nozzle, converting thermal energy into kinetic energy. A novel organic 18 vapor cycle employing isothermal expansion utilizing these nozzles is suggested to harness low- 19 grade heat sources. Nozzle experiments with air and water yielded a polytropic index <1.052, 20 enabling up to 71% more work extraction than adiabatic expansion. Simulations on a small-scale 21 heat engine indicate that utilizing these nozzles for thrust generation enables decreasing heat 22 transfer irreversibilities in the cycle, consequently resulting in up to 19% higher power output 23 than the organic Rankine cycle using Pentane. This work paves the way for an efficient and 24 high-power heat-to-power solution. 25 1 arXiv:2502.11082v1 [physics.app-ph] 16 Feb 2025
